# Get Started

Slate.css is an unopinionated CSS framework for rapid web layout and design. Slate is not a bunch of components, but rather utilities to help designers build faster ðŸš€

# Layout

Let's begin with the main component of any CSS framework; the layout.

# Grid

Any element can become a grid with the grid class. Grid elements have 12 columns. Below is an example of a common header, content, sidebar, and footer layout using Slate.

<div class="grid">
  <header></header>
  <main class="s9"></main>
  <aside class="s3"></aside>
  <footer></footer>
</div>

# Grid Column Sizes

Grid elements can span from 1 to 12 columns. An element with a class of s1 will span 1 column wide, whereas s12 will span the full width.

Say you want an element to start at column 4 and span until the end. Simply give the element a span value of s4-

# Render

When creating a new layout, it can be difficult to see where the elements will be positioned without content. Use the render class on the parent element to give all children a subtle grey background.

Here's an example of a grid element with the render class added.

<div class="grid render">
  <header></header>
  <main class="s9"></main>
  <aside class="s3"></aside>
  <footer></footer>
</div>

At times you may require different height elements to better preview your design. These elements will provide more or less height in your render elements. .sm .md .lg

.sm will give the element a minimum height of 100px. .md will give a minimum height of 250px. .lg will give a minimum height of 500px.

Here's what the render element will look like with these additions.

<div class="grid render">
  <header></header>
  <main class="s9 md"></main>
  <aside class="s3"></aside>
  <footer class="sm"></footer>
</div>

# Complex Grid Layouts

Sure columns are easy to deal with when you have them side-by-side. What if you need your content to start on the fourth column of the grid?

Sure you could add an empty div of s4 before the element, but that defeats the purpose of grid.

This is where the from element comes in handy.

# From

With the From class you can tell the element to start on a specific column of a grid and span the rest of the width.

Ex: .s4-. This is telling the element to start on the fourth column and span the rest of the width.

The dash means you want to start the element on that specific column. Without it, Slate will interpret the element as a span element and make it span 4 columns.

<div class="grid">
  <header></header>
  <main class="s4-"></main>
  <footer></footer>
</div>

# From and To

Now, what if you need the element to span from and to? Simply append the end column number.

Ex: .s4-9

<div class="grid">
  <header></header>
  <main class="s4-9"></main>
  <footer></footer>
</div>

# Display

You can change the display of any element using the .inline .inline-block and .block classes.

TIP

Append -children to a display class to target the elements children. A good example of this would be if you needed multiple images side-by-side.

Below is an example of using the .inline-block-children class to achieve that.

<div class="inline-block-children">
  <img src="...">
  <img src="...">
  <img src="...">
  <img src="...">
</div>

# Text

Let's begin with font sizes. Font sizes range from a value of 1 to 12; .fs1 being equal to 0.25rem and .fs12 being equal to 3rem. The steps move in incremenets of 0.25rem.

.fs1 .fs2 .fs3 .fs4 .fs5 .fs1 .fs1
